title: 111_hr31
content: The Act may be cited as the "Lumbee Recognition Act". The Act of June 7, 1956 is amended to acknowledge the Lumbee Indians of North Carolina as descendants of coastal tribes, recognized by the State since 1885 and by Congress in 1956. The Lumbee Indians should be granted full Federal recognition as an Indian tribe, along with the benefits and privileges that come with this status. The Lumbee Indians seek full Federal recognition as an Indian tribe. The Act of June 7, 1956 is amended to extend Federal recognition to the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina. Laws and regulations applicable to Indian tribes will now apply to the Lumbee Tribe and its members. Other groups of Indians in certain counties may also petition for tribal acknowledgement. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina and its members are eligible for services and benefits provided to federally recognized tribes. Members residing in specific counties are considered to be on or near an Indian reservation. The Secretary of the Interior will verify a tribal roll, and develop a determination of needs with the Lumbee Tribe for eligible services, submitting it to Congress. The Secretary of the Interior will verify the tribal roll for the Lumbee Tribe to define the service population, with verification limited to membership criteria. The Secretary may take land into trust for the tribe in Robeson County, North Carolina, for on-reservation trust acquisition. The tribe is prohibited from conducting gaming activities. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina is prohibited from conducting gaming activities and the State of North Carolina has jurisdiction over criminal offenses and civil actions on lands owned by the tribe. The Secretary of the Interior can accept transfers from the State of North Carolina on behalf of the United States. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina may transfer jurisdiction to the United States, subject to an agreement with the State of North Carolina. This transfer would not take effect until 2 years after the agreement. This provision does not impact the Indian Child Welfare Act. Funding is authorized for implementing this Act. The House of Representatives passed the bill on June 3, 2009.
